support_summary: After transport to the Golgi, ATF6 is sequentially cleaved by Site-1 Protease (S1P) and Site-2 Protease (S2P) to release its active cytosolic transcription factor domain.

functions.cellular_process: Upon ER stress, ATF6, freed from BiP, translocates from the ER to the Golgi apparatus. Within the cis/medial-Golgi, Site-1 Protease (S1P), also known as MBTPS1, recognizes and cleaves ATF6 within its luminal domain.
functions.effect_description: This initial cleavage by S1P separates the bulk of the luminal domain from the rest of the ATF6 protein. This event is an essential prerequisite for the subsequent cleavage by Site-2 Protease (S2P), as it removes steric hindrance.
biological_consequence: ATF6 translocates to the Golgi → S1P cleaves the ATF6 luminal domain → The large luminal portion of ATF6 is removed → The remainder of the ATF6 protein becomes a viable substrate for S2P → Sequential activation of ATF6 proceeds.
specific_effects: Catalyzes the first of two proteolytic cleavages required for ATF6 activation.
Reduces the size of the ATF6 luminal domain, thereby removing a steric block that prevents S2P from accessing its cleavage site.

evidence.paper_title: ER stress induces cleavage of membrane-bound ATF6 by the same proteases that process SREBPs
evidence.relevant_quote: Here, we show that ATF6 is processed by Site-1 protease (S1P) and Site-2 protease (S2P), the enzymes that process SREBPs in response to cholesterol deprivation. ATF6 processing was blocked completely in cells lacking S2P and partially in cells lacking S1P.

evidence.paper_title: Dependence of site-2 protease cleavage of ATF6 on prior site-1 protease digestion is determined by the size of the luminal domain of ATF6
evidence.relevant_quote: These results suggest that the bulky ATF6 luminal domain blocks S2P cleavage and that the role of S1P is to reduce the size of the luminal domain to prepare ATF6 to be an optimal S2P substrate.

mechanism: Upon ER stress, ATF6, freed from BiP, translocates from the ER to the Golgi apparatus. Within the cis/medial-Golgi, Site-1 Protease (S1P), also known as MBTPS1, recognizes and cleaves ATF6 within its luminal domain.
effect: This initial cleavage by S1P separates the bulk of the luminal domain from the rest of the ATF6 protein. This event is an essential prerequisite for the subsequent cleavage by Site-2 Protease (S2P), as it removes steric hindrance.
summary: ATF6 activates S1P to modulate initial proteolytic cleavage of atf6, ultimately affecting sequential activation of atf6 proceeds.
